text: I was teaching at University of Texas
and I was teaching a class in
interactive design and and this was in
the sort of late 90s and the internet
had had gotten really big and my
students were grappling with Notions of
interface design and really trying to
figure out how do how do they engage
users um and so I brought in a project
where we began to study games and the
students began to design and redesign
games as a way to understand what is
good interactive design um and that's
was the first time that I'd actually
brought games into my own classroom
space and the first time that I took
people who'd never done game design and
put them in the role of a game designer
and it was a huge moment of Discovery
for me because my students learn more
about how to engage an audience how to
really uh communicate and and how to
create really interesting um unusual
kinds of spaces when they used game
design as a starting point even though
they weren't designing games eventually
the process of thinking like a game
designer gave them a whole tool set tool
set that they hadn't had previously um
and so that sort of set me along this
path where I began to say you know
there's something just interesting in in
this act of teaching people to design
games um and then I began to work with
kids and one of the most interesting
thing that happens when you work with
young people in designing games is how
um deep they go into the content and so
this is this question of where the math
and science um stuff might come
in when we look at kids and we talk
about that definition of who is a gamer
it's actually a really old definition
there it used to be a time when only a
certain population of kids played games
they tended to be boys and they tended
to be kind of geeky boys that were
hidden away in their basement the truth
is today when you look at who is playing
games particularly younger kids up to
about sixth or seventh grade it's all
kids um and most kids don't
self-identify themselves as Gamers if
you ask them about that identity um it's
just something that they do so there's
an assumption when we recruit kids for
the school that that all kids have to a
greater or lesser degree some experience
playing games and an interest in playing
games the school is not excuse me it's
not a vocational school that's intended
to graduate game designers so that isn't
actually any way that we talk about the
school um and so the kids that we get
are kids that are deeply interested
in um a school that might feel a little
bit different than a Traditional School
um they tend to be really creative kids
um that are um interested in ideas that
they'll have a chance to design stuff
and make stuff um they're kids that uh
tend to be you know in some sense um
High performing and having strong
interests um and those interests don't
necessarily have to be games but they
might be interested in reading or they
might be interested in sports but
they're kids that get passionate about
something something um and get excited
about a school that might help them
cultivate that
passion so at the model Quest is that
the teachers collaborate with game
designers to design the curriculum so
there's no expectation that teachers
have to be game designers in the way
that there's no expectation that the
game designers are going to be in the
classroom teaching day-to-day with the
kids um so the teachers that we
recruited mostly came from the public
school system we have a couple that
taught at private schools
previously um none of them had a game
design background uh a few of them had
an interest in games some of them had a
background in technology um but all of
them were uh strong collaborators had
worked in contexts where collaboration
was key all of them were uh deeply
interested in the craft of of learning
and and how to really work with kids um
and all of them were open to the idea of
uh being a curriculum designer and uh
working with game designers and trying
to see where this model could could
really take learning for kids
I would say that it's it's not so much
among our parents um because any open
house or talk that they might come to
where they hear about the school becomes
really clear how we're talking about
games um and how we value them but there
is a larger cultural discourse um that I
think is quite limited around this issue
of what's the value of games and what's
the value of play um and video games in
particular because they've been covered
I think historically in the the
media as either uh games that are about
violence or games that are about wasting
time those are the two kind of dominant
narratives that people that don't know
much about games hear again and again
and again and so it's a bit of a
default um position that people fall
into just because they haven't perhaps
really thought about it um any parent
that that we have that has a child that
spends an amount of time gaming at home
actually understands something about why
that child is gaming and what they're
getting out of it and partially it is
because they talk to the kids um and
those reasons really vary sometimes the
the value of the gaming is uh around the
the social structure and the community
that the kids have we find that that
gaming is less about the artifact of the
game itself and more about the community
that sort of sits around that game and
that players are part of and for many
parents that social piece is pretty big
for kids
um for other parents there is a
opportunity around creativity that they
see happening in these games they also
see their kids persisting on problems in
games that they don't see them
persisting on in other faes and they
begin to recognize that that persistence
and tenacity is actually something
pretty important they don't really know
how to make it happen in other kinds of
spaces but they they see their kids
doing that and they think wow if I could
get my kid to do that when they're
working on math
be that persistent there's something
really valuable there um so I think it's
more this General cultural dialogue
that's pretty um pretty narrow and
pretty underdeveloped at the moment and
and part of the goal of this school as
well of some you know a lot of other
people doing work in the space is to try
to complexify the argument um and begin
to understand that you know historically
from the moment that human being sort of
came into existence play was a part of
culture it was a profound part of what
makes us human a profound part of what
keeps a community together a profound
part of ways in which we uh can deal
with complex issues that are maybe too
uh complicated to deal with outside a
kind of play Space um and so the the
notion and value of play historically
has been huge and it doesn't make sense
to me today why we would dismiss it um
because it's something that we see
embodied in a way that maybe we don't
understand in understand in some digital
games that um for many people look kind
of scary
